Why 'Our Future Our Choice' will Never Win Over Leavers

14/01/2019

...Or why I learned to stop caring and write for Nouse

Image by

By James Bithell

Oh no, not another one? Yep! Some other arsehole has written their unique, witty take about Brexit that MUST be thrown right into the faces of a small group of people who really don't care what I have to say. Seriously, the debate over Brexit isn't just beating a dead horse anymore, it's all about finding any pony in the stables that looks like it might be related. Well here I am, club in hand, searching for any last twitching in what must be one of the greatest acts of animal abuse in British political history. Normally, I feel like this sort of thing should be beneath me, or indeed any normal person with an opinion. Believe it or not, lots of people who have opinions are actually quite smart, or at bare minimum a little bit smart. They have reasons for their opinions and don't want some jumped up student who happens to be friends with an editor to let them churn some shite in their face, insulting every fibre of their being and yet, here I am! Why? Well there's some takes that still need to be shared and while I'm free, I might as well. Anyway, to the actual point.

As a student who wished he worked hard enough at A-Levels to study politics, I'm thoroughly interested in the political debates, the back and forths, and the intellectual duels to the death, happening all over campus. All these bright-eyed youngsters like me, out there to make arguments and convince people of their deeply held convictions. This has never been bigger than the 'Brexit era'. Sure everyone's already said Brexit is the biggest so and so for whatever many years, but it really has engaged some students to a phenomenal level. Any wannabe politico must have an opinion on it. And that was years ago! Now it's got enough diplomatic nooks and trade agreement crannies to warrant all sorts of daft level insights and documentaries. As a brief aside, is it true that the BBC are making something about the body language of Brexit? I saw it on twitter once or something...anyway.  

When I first saw this sort of thing, it was great! But like a naive school boy looking at an empty kennel wondering where Rex has gone, it doesn't take long to figure out something isn't right. This isn't actually the death arena of debate that my creepy History teacher said University would be. And there's a very simple cause to all this. Nobody's actually out to convince people of their position. Not really. They're not there to 'convince the muggles' as a friend who's only ever read 1 book once told me. Sure, they go out there and make some interesting points, maybe get a few people rowdy, but their express purpose is very rarely to make people come onto their side by explaining why their arguments are stronger. And I want to make it clear that both sides are guilty of this. For every Owen Jones there's a Raheem Kassam (just two people I don't care about) out there just to annoy people, but I think I'd get support from almost all sides of the Brexit polygon that the soul of this evil lies within the FBPE (Follow Back Pro-EU) crowd.

Yeah, I'm talking about you Our Future Our Choice (OFOC), with your nice clean logo and brilliant website user interface. There's so much that can be said about Best for Britain and Open Britain. Maybe even the historic European Movement UK (EMUK) deserves to be levied some criticism, but I really want to focus this onto the student wings, the youth groups, partially because it's easier to rant about the daft things I see personally, and partially because I have a lot of respect for the former President of EMUK, the late, great Paddy Ashdown.

Back to the point again, OFOC really do wind me up. And for good reason. Its a group who's seeming only purpose is to turn everyone it touches into a machine to hate the idea of leaving the EU. Don't get me wrong, there's a lot to hate, but even being charitable, that's not really what it's about. On the face of it, this group is meant to motivate people into having a second referendum right? But it provides very few critical arguments of its own to push for this. To say that so and so many people were never given their opportunity to vote for instance, is not an argument about Brexit. It's not going to convince the actual Brexit voters, who by and large just wanted to see laws made in this country is it. Sure, it's a very good argument to criticise the use of referenda in a parliamentary democracy, but that's not how it's presented. Like Jeremy Clarkson talking about that time he got thrown out of Argentina, you can never expect it to be presented in a truly honest manner.

And it only gets worse from there. Every petition that's done on that government petition website that gets 100,000 signatures, there's always another saying the exact opposite. Every time Femi Oluwole gets a quick appearance on the telly, Tom Harwood gets to splurge another spicy take into the atmosphere. Forget the Great War (it's past the centenary I'm allowed to make jokes about it now), this is the greatest war of attrition in history, and it'll never end. Unless I suppose Farage is planning on remaking the battle of the Somme, which is entirely possible.

So what's the point of all this bollocks then? Well I actually want to get a message out there. I want to communicate to this crowd, and give them the cutting edge that'll push them to victory, because I'm sick of hearing about this shit frankly. You there, member of Our Future Our Choice! Yeah, you! You need to do two things Look at why people voted, they have their own reasons! It's mainly just so that laws are made here, right? So if you calmly show how there might be more value to supranationalism, maybe you can change some minds. If you explain how greater oversight, consistent regional governance and unified law might benefit the people of this country, then maybe you'll engage actual leave voters more than painting your face blue, making Brexit poetry and talking about that bloody bus. Secondly, and I get the irony here don't worry, but don't be condescending to people (that's when you talk down to someone). There's nothing wrong in admitting that the EU has done some daft things in the past, and you'd be just fine to accept that. There's no need, however, to jump on the bandwagon and assume that there can be no good reason to leave, so everyone must be a bastard for wanting to. I know it's not original to say, but when you see normal people routinely insulted and irritated by people who don't actually understand their convictions, then I feel it has to be said yet again.

So there you go, another great big shite into the sewer of loneliness that is the Nouse Comment section. I realise that this may cause some agitation if they've taken in what I've said, and to be honest, I'm sorry. This isn't a piece meant to fight against a movement, it's just trying to help people who I think are perhaps misguided in their aims. And there are some lovely people who support these groups and don't belittle people! It is possible! Either way, everyone should just accept that nobody cares about your fucking Brexit take, move on with your life knowing that and you'll live happy. Or put it in a student newspaper. I heard The Lemon Press is quite good.
